 Day of Defeat is the last skill-based FPS game made. Per-pixel accuracy, anticipation, map awareness, reflexes, it had it all without being a complete spas fest like Quake. The added "realistic" nuances of modern FPS such as larger maps, larger player matches, movement penalties, class/archetype dependencies have only taken away from the pure competitive FPS experience. Unfortunately, this style of FPS is an end of an era, encapsulated in its time. Games that try to fuse this with modern elements such as the latest Counter Strike releases feel dated. The last attempt to revive this title (Source) also tried fusing modern elements to gameplay but compromised what made DOD unique and great in the first place.

												Despite it's age, ''Day of Defeat'' is still alive and doing well. A lot of the players are non-Steam, so the charts are only correct for the Steam users. It's a WW2 shooter with realism. It is very hard to get into this game since it has a big learning curve and pretty much everyone is extremely good. Most of the maps are very well made and balanced. There are a few narrow maps which are a slaughterhouse if there are too many players though. I believe that there are things you should know before playing this game, so here are a few words of advice: - Grenades are very powerful- Grenades are detonated quicker if you pull the pin and do not throw it for a while - Most Grenadier and Sniper shots will be a one shot kill - In narrow maps it will be very frustrating, so play on larger maps first - Automatic weapons have recoil which is very hard to handle, so take your time to learn the basics of each weapon - Constantly check the map to see if you have teammates around, so you know if it's safe to push - You will die. A LOT.That's pretty much it. Things like spots, weapons, maps and tricks you will learn along the way of playing it. First few hours will be very frustrating, especially for someone who hasn't played realistic shooters, but you will find yourself scoring more and more kills over time and it will be very satisfying. So, give this game a shot even if at first glance you think that the game is bad or everyone is too good or cheating. It is one of the best WW2/Realism games I've played for sure.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												Day of Defeat is a WW2 themed multiplayer team and class-based game of capturing and holding off points. Capturing points is not the only gamemode, but most played, if not only one, around. You could get betas of the game for free as mods for Half-Life 1, but the final versions were released as paid Retail product by Valve. And as you can see, it got on Steam too.First thing first, since it's a multiplayer title... How is community of this old game? It's doing well! It may not have overwhelming amount of players, but you will always find few almost-full servers. And while dod_avalanche map appears to be favourite among the community, you still will get to enjoy some maps variety on various servers. Not so much on game type variety though, capturing the flags points is most played.As said, Day of Defeat is a WW2 shooter. Team and class based. A mix between arcade and realism. Weapons are as deadly as in many such shooters, just having single person rush forward will do no good, should do that in team. Many weapons also have big recoil, which depends on your stance: moving, standing, crouching or prone. Being prone is the slowest and clunkiest, easy to hit from above, but harder from long distances, also giving character almost no recoil when shooting. Yes, camping is a viable strategy here, but I feel that I have more chance to break through camping than in, say, Counter-strike. Players can respawn any time, so putting yourself to risk isn't bad idea. Each character also have a stamina, which is used when you spring and jump, slowly recovering afterwards. The slowing effect after using it is quite punishing, so you should sprint from cover to cover. Don't use sprint when moving to the front from the spawn point.Maps are designed to be more of pipes, like classic maps, not open fields, providing a main path and few flanking routes. Even more curious, the maps are assymetrical, which may possibly provide some inbalance (I think that Nazis in Avalanche map have height advantage). Breaks the usual symmetry monotony though, more interesting. Some maps even feature British forces instead of American ones. (they have less classes though)No, this one doesn't have vehicles, it is not Battlefield after all. Each team has up to 10 classes. The only difference most have is primary weapon and whether they have or not grenades to spam at corners and choke points. None have ironsight, if you wonder, aside from scope for sniper rifles. And most of primary weapons tend to be quite similiar to each other, which I don't like, as I prefer classes to be more diverce... something what Day Of Defeat Source did. Classes can be divided into:1) Close Range Assault classes - have guns with light recoil, good for running and gunning, and then getting one-hit killed by another rushing rifleman.2) Assault Support classes - more recoil, medium range, they better occasionally crouch or stand to be able to litter enemies with bullets at close range.Close range and Support get mixed a bit together, making other classes.3) Riflemans - Killing mens with one bullet per few seconds, medium-long range class. Well, and short one too. Only bad when rushed by few mens. Just crouch occasionally4) Machine Gunners - limited, they can deploy their machine gun on sandbags or while prone. Their machine gun allows them to give your team control over area. Just watch out for snipers and grenade spam. No grenades.5) Snipers - not really much of different from Rifleman, just got scope and more accurate while scoped. No grenades though.6) Bazooka - You got rocket launcher. And if you imagine infantry going "whee" from rocket - too bad. It's a utility weapon, which only very few maps have use for, like blowing tank in some map (that I didn't get to play in public servers yet). Very annoying whenever Random keeps giving you this class.The graphics technically are quite outdated, but still provide it's own quirk. The music is almost non-existing. Only main theme and victory tunes are there.So, nice game, especially when measured with other HL1 mods. Still fun and still has active multiplayer. But the people who don't like hitscan weapons and who like to get right into action, it's not for them.

												A true classic from the days when half a dozen guys in their basements could work together to produce the best game they could because they wanted to play the best.  The simple, predictable mechanics of the GoldSource engine give you a level of fine control over movement that greatly contributes to the depth of the gameplay. Once you get passed the initial learning curve, you'll have some adrenaline-pumping moments, sneaking behind enemy lines, going on fast-paced rampages, chucking an enemy's grenade right back into his face.  The community is quite mature and friendly and has a relatively high proportion of female gamers.  There are still some very good servers going, and at the right time of day you can still play on a couple of full servers.  There are hundreds of custom maps, many of them every bit as good or better than the official maps. It's great to play a game knowing that you're helping the other people playing be able to enjoy themselves.It's cheap, buy it, stick with it for a bit, and help keep this awesome community alive.

												This game has no bells and whistles. It is all straight forward first-person shooter online action. Just player model and weapon - single shot rifles, semi-auto machine guns, sniper, machine gun, bazooka, and knife (or bayonet and trench shovel). What makes this game excellent? The game lends itself well to teamplay with excellent voice over microphone. The sound in the game is very good, and listening is a critical part of playing well. The Day of Defeat community is extensive and skilled and has produced an enormous amount of modified material. There are tons and tons of player created custom maps which are equal in quality to the core of 20 stock maps which come with the game. Half-Life is the greatest shooter game ever. So is it any doubt that this ww2-based modification of Half-Life is the greatest WW2 shooter? It has been around for 13 years now, so the skill level of the player base is fairly high. However, DOD players are usually well-helpful to new players. If you like running and gunning in a WW2 environment, you gotta give this game a try. Posted: January 10, 2015
												Day of Defeat is a WW2 themed multiplayer team and class-based game of capturing and holding off points. Capturing points is not the only gamemode, but most played, if not only one, around. You could get betas of the game for free as mods for Half-Life 1, but the final versions were released as paid Retail product by Valve. And as you can see, it got on Steam too.First thing first, since it's a multiplayer title... How is community of this old game? It's doing well! It may not have overwhelming amount of players, but you will always find few almost-full servers. And while dod_avalanche map appears to be favourite among the community, you still will get to enjoy some maps variety on various servers. Not so much on game type variety though, capturing the flags points is most played.As said, Day of Defeat is a WW2 shooter. Team and class based. A mix between arcade and realism. Weapons are as deadly as in many such shooters, just having single person rush forward will do no good, should do that in team. Many weapons also have big recoil, which depends on your stance: moving, standing, crouching or prone. Being prone is the slowest and clunkiest, easy to hit from above, but harder from long distances, also giving character almost no recoil when shooting. Yes, camping is a viable strategy here, but I feel that I have more chance to break through camping than in, say, Counter-strike. Players can respawn any time, so putting yourself to risk isn't bad idea. Each character also have a stamina, which is used when you spring and jump, slowly recovering afterwards. The slowing effect after using it is quite punishing, so you should sprint from cover to cover. Don't use sprint when moving to the front from the spawn point.Maps are designed to be more of pipes, like classic maps, not open fields, providing a main path and few flanking routes. Even more curious, the maps are assymetrical, which may possibly provide some inbalance (I think that Nazis in Avalanche map have height advantage). Breaks the usual symmetry monotony though, more interesting. Some maps even feature British forces instead of American ones. (they have less classes though)No, this one doesn't have vehicles, it is not Battlefield after all. Each team has up to 10 classes. The only difference most have is primary weapon and whether they have or not grenades to spam at corners and choke points. None have ironsight, if you wonder, aside from scope for sniper rifles. And most of primary weapons tend to be quite similiar to each other, which I don't like, as I prefer classes to be more diverce... something what Day Of Defeat Source did. Classes can be divided into:1) Close Range Assault classes - have guns with light recoil, good for running and gunning, and then getting one-hit killed by another rushing rifleman.2) Assault Support classes - more recoil, medium range, they better occasionally crouch or stand to be able to litter enemies with bullets at close range.Close range and Support get mixed a bit together, making other classes.3) Riflemans - Killing mens with one bullet per few seconds, medium-long range class. Well, and short one too. Only bad when rushed by few mens. Just crouch occasionally4) Machine Gunners - limited, they can deploy their machine gun on sandbags or while prone. Their machine gun allows them to give your team control over area. Just watch out for snipers and grenade spam. No grenades.5) Snipers - not really much of different from Rifleman, just got scope and more accurate while scoped. No grenades though.6) Bazooka - You got rocket launcher. And if you imagine infantry going "whee" from rocket - too bad. It's a utility weapon, which only very few maps have use for, like blowing tank in some map (that I didn't get to play in public servers yet). Very annoying whenever Random keeps giving you this class.The graphics technically are quite outdated, but still provide it's own quirk. The music is almost non-existing. Only main theme and victory tunes are there.So, nice game, especially when measured with other HL1 mods. Still fun and still has active multiplayer. But the people who don't like hitscan weapons and who like to get right into action, it's not for them.

												Whether looking for an old game to play to remember the days before steam, or because nothing else will work on your computer, this is an ok buy, but only if on sale.The original Day of Defeat, graphics wise, looks like♥♥♥♥♥♥ Half life, CS 1.6 and TFC look far better than this, and they are much older. Trees, Barbed wire, and various vegetation textures are glitched, and will somtimes not be transparent as they should be. effects are also, unreasonably crappy, as grenades do not show an actual explosion, unlike most older HL games (keep in mind this game runs on another engine, though), and gun fire creates and unjustifiably large, half♥♥♥♥♥♥♥light effect.Gameplay is not terrible, though certain effects form jumping, running, and going prone can be annoying. There are many diverse classes with unique weapons, and sometimes even map specific weapons and gamemodes. Most maps are conquest, while some are search and destroy. Unlike CS there is respawning, but on wave timers. Controls are ok on default, but I would recommend some custumization, as some keys, like flashlight, are stupidly placed (it's "n"). Some maps are poorly lit, quite a few are unnecessarily large, and most are designed so that the battles of WW2 end up more like WW1. A bloody stalemate in the middle of the map that shifts forward occaisionally, only to be stopped by someone in a bottleneck with an MG.While there is still a community, there are alot of empty servers, so lukily there are mods for bots. While playing can be pretty frustrating at times, it's still a fun game to play, and is far better than it's source counterpart. Get it during a sale.

												I really like this game, like really. First got into it when a PCGamer Magazine featured beta 1.3 in one of their CDRoms that came with the magazine, back in 2001 I think. Stopped playing for a while in the middle of the decade, picked it up again a few years ago, and have been playing pretty regularly.For new players, a little advice, please change your name before entering your first game. Communication is key, don't get sniped and neglect to tell your team where the sniper is.Do not sit in one spot for too long. Some of these guys have been playing since before you were born and can hit any spot on the map. Crouch and shoot unless you're caught unawares, then make yourself a moving target and aim for the head. Stay in cover, but if you kill someone move your position, good teams communicate. Don't take the mg to the top of the bank on Caen or to either sniper loft, you will die very fast. Learn to snipe on your feet, laying down and sniping is the worst. Try to vary your routine, if you choose the same route too often, experienced players will learn to anticipate you. When sniping an exit from the side, place your crosshair a few feet in front of the exit to give yourself enough space to shoot a streaking opposing player exiting. Throw your nades on the ground and pick them up, hold them for a sec and then throw them [holding time will vary]. If you use an automatic weapon, aim at center mass and quickly streak up to the head. When walking let your crosshairs naturally rest in a slightly elevated position, that way if you suddenly come upon an enemy, you will likely already be aiming at his head [beware, pros will crouch to avoid this very thing [ofc they'll also jump to avoid your shot, idk do your best]]. Fire in short bursts. Change your crosshairs to dynamic instead of static. Have fun. This game is great, there is a core community left that is mostly polite and old. But there is still some young blood, like me and others. Try out the Merrill's Marauder's 24/7 Caen and Avalanche servers. They are consistently full and well administrated. I'm usually on in the afternoon/night. GG.

												Not sure why I have not already written a review for this game. Better late than never, especially with Day of Defeat!This game is like wine! It's a bit old, it may even be a little ugly in some areas, but Day of Defeat is still one of the best online FPS games on Steam. Unlike other Gold Source games like CS 1.6 and Half-Life, DoD is a realistic and terrifyingly ambient take on the close quarters combat scenarios of the second World War. The game is dark and somewhat nerve-wracking; buildings are smothered to rubble, the cities are dark and shaded, and the sounds of the war are all around. The realism of the weaponry gives the player a greater sense of responsibility as each class has a specific role. Things such as muzzle flashes, footsteps, reloading, squad commands, and changing weapons makes a sound that must be considered when operating on the battlefield. Needless to say, Day of Defeat is a game everyone needs in their library! DoD is not so realistic as to have an almost "cheesy" outward appearance (like Red Orchestra), but it is not your average FPS online shooter - no "jump shotting", "quick scoping", "'nade spamming", etc. - Day of Defeat relies on the seriousness of the player, and the cohesiveness of the team. If you are used to playing Day of Defeat: Source, I would suggest buying DoD Original as there are a lot of things this game has that DoD:S does not: more weaponry, ambient maps, gameplay opportunities, and the ability to play as the Royal Army. According to steam stats the game has ~200 players (30 day average). Source has around three to four times that number at time of writing. If you're considering buying DoD:Source over this one; Don't.I've played DoD since it's early mod days, this is it's superior form.Forget the graphics, forget a lot of fancy new features. This game's simply the better choice.As far as a Multiplayer game goes if you've never played, it's good if you have some friends who also are interested in psuedo-realistic fast paced respawn fps, especially set durring WW2. Two teams fight over control points to win each round. Both teams have a variety of weapons with different pro's/con's to choose from, stats are visable for weapons. There are NO VEHICLES, There are lots of WW2 military vehicles props that populate the map to be used as cover, for HL1 mods that was sort of rare. It is pretty easy to die, respawning isn't random, set locations. Team work and expenditur of ammo is promoted with the general gameplay / map flow and most base classes (Rifleman spawn with 11 clips or so, to promote suppressive fire). Team work in this game generally means; just sticking together, noticing what type of firepower and directions your team mates generally check or cover / filling in those gaps, if theres no support/machine gunners on your team, taking that class and trying to fill the roll to the best of your general knowledge.The Con's;-Not a lot of populated servers these days, this version does support many different bot scripts though (cant say if Source does or not).-Does get tiring after awhile, it's repititve but simple.-If you use a CRT monitor (LoL I'm so sorry for you) then stop right now, this game is probably too dark on your monitor to play. Since most people don't have CRT monitors any more, you can probably look past this issue, newer LCD's or brighter LCD's have no worry.-Doesn't really play as a 'lone wolf' kind of game, more team work or support of one another in some caring way is needed to progress and not end up sucking all the time. -Maps are almost all urban or city, some openess to them but going back to an older FPS, they don't really feel that 'expansive' of distances, one issue the source port fixed directly I feel.

												This game is a first person shooter, like all other Valve titles. You can tell it's dated by how it plays, and the mouse moves a bit weirdly, but it's no big deal.Day of Defeat is one of those games where you play it for a very long time the first time, and then leave it forever. It becomes very repetitive. The choice of weapons is short, and the maps on most servers are few and far between. The gameplay is a bit awkward, where everything feels clunky, and dodging flying grenades is difficult.One thing I will mention is the Community. Man, if there were no community, there would be no game. Peopel are always communicating. About their personal lives, about the game, about strategy, about what to do next and how to work together. The community is truly one of the game's strongest points, and it made me enjoy the heck out of talking with people.The soundtrack is another big point. I really enjoyed listening to the victory themes for both sides, as well as the front page. It has this interesting antique WW2 feeling to it, and I really liked it.All in all, I do not recommend this game. Just get Day of Defeat: Source if you were really thinking of buying a Day of Defeat title. It has more people and servers on it anyways.

content:
Posted: June 2, 2013
												Day Of Defeat is another of the free modifications for Half-Life that, with the help of Valve, got turned into a full fledged retail release. Often overshadowed by it's significantly more popular older brother, Counter-Strike, Day Of Defeat is a relatively unknown to many and while it doesn't quite live up to the standards set by similar retail games it does provide a decent World War II experience.Day Of Defeat pits the German Army against either the British or American forces, which one is chosen depends on the map being played, in relatively small surroundings. Although it is not a game that aims for any sort of uber realism it does feature a number of mechanics to encourage slower and more realistic behavior such as a stamina bar and significantly decreased accuracy when moving. Respawning into the battle happens in waves which keeps the action going and prevents too much downtime but unfortunately also encourages less entertaining behavior such as spawn camping.The class based system is fairly limited and only changes the weapons you use which creates a rather bland experience.Graphically it is clear that the old Half-Life engine has run it's course, Day Of Defeat is by no means a good looking game and the lack of detail can get distracting at times especially when considering that it's main rival is the stellar looking Battlefield 1942.All in all Day Of Defeat is a mod success. The people that played it before it turned retail are the people that's going to play it afterwards, it's not a game that's looking to pick up any new fans in the transition. Perhaps it is easier to understand if you view this, not as a game going from mod to retail. But as a team of developers going from amateurs to professionals. It is an astonishing accomplishment and I wish them all the best in their future endeavors, I am just not really sure I want to pay for their advancement.
